questions.text: A patient who has a pet dog, came with a complaint of hypochondrial pain. The radiological imaging showed cyst within the liver. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Echinococcus granulosus, also known as the dog tapeworm, can cause hydatid cyst disease in humans, with multilocular cysts commonly found in the liver. Owning a pet dog and ingesting food or water contaminated with dog feces containing the parasite's eggs are risk factors for acquiring this infection.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can exacerbate the condition by promoting the growth of endometriotic lesions

questions.text: Where sharp waste can be disposed? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) White container

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came with the symptoms of drooping of eyelid, difficulty in chewing, weakness in the hands which increases as the day progresses. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by symptoms such as drooping of the eyelids, difficulty in chewing, and progressive muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, showing a decremental response upon repeated stimulation.

questions.text: A person came to the OPD with a history of fall on the outstretched hand and now has an injury at the anatomical snuff box. Which bone is most commonly fractured at this site? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scaphoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured.
  • • The scaphoid bone is the second most common bone to suffer avascular necrosis after the head of the femur. When a person falls on an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the wrist, making the scaphoid bone vulnerable to fracture. The anatomical snuff box is an important anatomical landmark with five different clinical points related to it.
  • • To test for a scaphoid fracture, the "glass holding position" can be used, where the thumb adopts a specific position that stresses the scaphoid bone.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lunate : Although the lunate is a carpal bone, it is not the most commonly fractured bone at the anatomical snuff box site.
  • • Option A. Lunate
  • • Option C. Trapezium: The trapezium is one of the bones that can be palpated in the anatomical snuff box ("then try to catch her, she means trapezium"), but it is not the most commonly fractured bone in this scenario.
  • • Option C. Trapezium:
  • • Option D. Pisiform: The pisiform is a small carpal bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, not in the anatomical snuff box, and is not commonly fractured in a fall on an outstretched hand.
  • • Option D. Pisiform:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand.
  • ➤ Note –
  • ➤ Note –
  • ➤ MC bone getting avascular necrosis – head of the femur 2 nd most common bone getting avascular necrosis – Scaphoid MC carpal bone getting fractured - scaphoid
  • ➤ MC bone getting avascular necrosis – head of the femur
  • ➤ 2 nd most common bone getting avascular necrosis – Scaphoid
  • ➤ MC carpal bone getting fractured - scaphoid

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chi Square test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ocrelizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocrelizumab is the only drug currently shown to be effective in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS).
  • ➤ Remember - The drug that has been shown to be effective in treating secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) is Siponimod, which is a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor agonist.
  • ➤ Remember

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: An elderly male on bed rest for many months presented with breathlessness and chest pain. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard investigation for confirming pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes to the OPD for a regular check-up. She has decreased iron levels and the doctor prescribed her iron medication. Which of the following decreases the iron absorption from the gut? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tea contains tannins that decrease iron absorption from the gut by binding to non-heme iron and forming insoluble complexes.

questions.text: Identify the shown congenital anomaly in which the intestinal loops are present outside the abdominal cavity covered by amniotic membrane. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a congenital anomaly known as omphalocele. This condition is characterized by the presence of intestinal loops and sometimes other abdominal organs outside the abdominal cavity. These organs are covered by a transparent sac composed of the amniotic membrane, peritoneum, and Wharton's jelly.
  • • Omphalocele Characteristics: In omphalocele, the herniated organs protrude through the umbilical ring and are covered by the amniotic membrane. This condition is associated with various other congenital anomalies and syndromes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis : This is incorrect. In gastroschisis, the intestines protrude through a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilical cord, without any covering membrane. The exposed intestines are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which distinguishes it from omphalocele.
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst : This is incorrect. While an omphalocele can be associated with various anomalies, the specific mention of an enteric cyst is not a standard characteristic of typical omphalocele presentations.
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. Gastroschisis involves exposed intestines without a covering membrane. The presence of an enteric cyst does not align with the typical presentation of gastroschisis.
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the intestines and possibly other organs protrude through the umbilical ring, covered by the amniotic membrane. This differentiates it from gastroschisis, where the intestines are exposed without a covering membrane.

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? ( INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

Explanation:

  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR) :
  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR)
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation
  • • Rapid Antigen Test :
  • • Rapid Antigen Test
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) :
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: Airway resistance in endotracheal tube is dependent on: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diameter of the tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding Poiseuille's law is crucial for selecting appropriate endotracheal tubes. The diameter of the tube has the most significant impact on airway resistance. A larger diameter tube will decrease resistance, facilitating easier ventilation and oxygenation of the patient.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High estrogen levels inhibit milk production during pregnancy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6 th edition

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chickenpox

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description and image provided indicate a diagnosis of chickenpox (varicella). Key features include:
  • • chickenpox
  • • Generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. The lesions appear as "dew drops on a rose petal," which is characteristic of chickenpox. Chickenpox lesions are typically in various stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) at the same time.
  • • Generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk.
  • • Generalized vesicular eruptions
  • • The lesions appear as "dew drops on a rose petal," which is characteristic of chickenpox.
  • • Chickenpox lesions are typically in various stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) at the same time.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Smallpox: Presents with a more uniform appearance of lesions and typically starts on the face and extremities.
  • • Option A. Smallpox:
  • • Option C. Monkeypox: Presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a rash that is similar to smallpox but usually more severe.
  • • Option C. Monkeypox:
  • • Option D. Shingles: Generally presents in a dermatomal distribution and occurs in older individuals or those with a history of varicella.
  • • Option D. Shingles:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chickenpox is characterized by generalized vesicular eruptions that look like "dew drops on a rose petal" and appear in various stages simultaneously.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing loss of vision on both left sides of the visual fields, but retains the ability to see a small portion in the middle. Based on the history, where is the likely location of the lesion? ( FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Occipital cortex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in the occipital cortex can cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, where the patient loses vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes but retains central vision due to the dual blood supply to the macular region.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the Graph is suggestive of: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Michaelis Menten kinetics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The graph shows a hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaels - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.
  • • hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaels - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.
  • • Here, Vmax represents the maximum rate achieved by the system , happening at saturating substrate concentration for a given enzyme concentration. When the value of the Michaelis constant Km is numerically equal to the substrate concentration, then the reaction rate is half of Vmax. Biochemical reactions involving a single substrate are often assumed to follow Michaelis–Menten kinetics.
  • • Vmax represents the maximum rate achieved by the system
  • • Biochemical reactions involving a single substrate are often assumed to follow Michaelis–Menten kinetics.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • :
  • • Option A. Allosteric Activation: This typically results in a sigmoid (S-shaped) curve rather than a hyperbolic one, as allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding.
  • • Option A. Allosteric Activation:
  • • Option B. Cooperative Binding: This is also characterized by a sigmoid curve, indicating that the binding of substrate to one active site affects the binding at other active sites.
  • • Option B. Cooperative Binding:
  • • Option D. Sigmoid Curve: This type of curve is associated with allosteric enzymes and cooperative binding, not with Michaelis-Menten kinetics.
  • • Option D. Sigmoid Curve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Michaelis-Menten kinetics is characterized by a hyperbolic curve where Vmax is the maximum rate achieved, and Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle , marked A in the given coronal CT image.
  • • Pott spine
  • • having persistent hip flexion
  • • psoas abscess
  • • involving the psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, no skin changes or infection are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphangiosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cause of unilateral limb swelling in a patient with a history of mastectomy, is most commonly due to lymphedema.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.
  • • The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.
  • • Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.
  • • Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include :
  • • Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include
  • • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah"). The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)
  • • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)
  • • Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.
  • • Option. A. 1:
  • • Option. C. 3 : This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.
  • • Option. C. 3
  • • Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.
  • • Option. D. 4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.

  • ➤ Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: What is given to prevent neural tube defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy is crucial to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occludens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Integrin : Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option A. Integrin
  • • Option B. Cadherin : Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option B. Cadherin
  • • Option D. None of the above : Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option D. None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: The type of cataract associated with blunt trauma is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rosette cataract is the type of cataract that develops following blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by its distinctive flower-like pattern.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. What will be the biopsy finding? (INICET NOV 2022) Thyroid transcription factor-1 P40 Napsin A Chromogranin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs act at the site marked by the arrow? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tiagabine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tiagabine acts by inhibiting GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), which is responsible for the reuptake of GABA from the synapse. By blocking this transporter, Tiagabine increases the synaptic concentration of GABA, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and providing antiepileptic effects. The name "Tiagabine" itself suggests its mechanism - Transport Inhibitor of GABA or GAT-1 inhibitor.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vigabatrin : Incorrect. It inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, not the GABA transporter. This increases GABA levels through a different mechanism.
  • • Option A. Vigabatrin
  • • Option B. Valproate : Incorrect. It has multiple mechanisms of action, primarily involving sodium channel blockade and enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition, but does not specifically target GAT-1.
  • • Option B. Valproate
  • • Option C. Felbamate : Incorrect. It acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist and enhances GABA-mediated inhibition through different mechanisms, not through GAT-1 inhibition.
  • • Option C. Felbamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake by blocking the GABA transporter (GAT-1), leading to increased extracellular GABA and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, making it an effective treatment for epilepsy.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: Identify the child whose growth is compromised: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Line C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pediatric health assessments, growth charts are critical tools. They help healthcare providers monitor a child's growth over time, comparing their progress against standardized percentile curves. A trajectory like "C", which falls below the 3rd percentile, warrants further investigation to determine the cause of the poor growth and to initiate appropriate interventions.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of wound healing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hemostasis, Inflammation, Proliferation, remodeling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct sequence of events in the wound healing process is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling.
  • • 1. Hemostasis: This is the first step in wound healing, where bleeding is stopped by the formation of a blood clot. This involves vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and the activation of the coagulation cascade.
  • • 1. Hemostasis:
  • • 2. Inflammation: After hemostasis, the inflammatory phase begins, which involves the influx of inflammatory cells (neutrophils, macrophages) to the wound site. These cells remove debris, bacteria, and damaged tissue, setting the stage for the next phase.
  • • 2. Inflammation:
  • • 3. Proliferation: In this phase, new blood vessels (angiogenesis) are formed, and fibroblasts proliferate and produce collagen, forming granulation tissue. This granulation tissue fills the wound and provides a matrix for the migration and proliferation of epithelial cells, leading to re-epithelialization.
  • • 3. Proliferation:
  • • 4. Remodeling: This is the final phase, where the newly formed collagen fibers are reorganized and cross-linked, leading to increased tensile strength. During this phase, the wound contracts, and excess cells and blood vessels are removed through apoptosis.
  • • 4. Remodeling:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of events in wound healing is hemostasis (stopping bleeding), inflammation (influx of inflammatory cells), proliferation (formation of granulation tissue, angiogenesis, and re-epithelialization), and remodeling (reorganization and cross-linking of collagen fibers).

questions.text: A 41-year-old construction worker in Uttar Pradesh collapsed at the construction site in the afternoon of a summer day. Which of the following is least likely to be seen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Sweating

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In classic heat stroke, typically caused by high environmental temperatures, the patient often presents with high body temperature, hypotension, and tachypnea, but lacks sweating. This distinguishes it from exertional heat stroke, where sweating might still be present.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with an acute ischemic stroke is undergoing thrombolysis with IV alteplase. He currently weighs 80 kg. What is the appropriate dose of alteplase to be given to this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 8 mg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient weighing 80 kg, the appropriate initial bolus dose of alteplase for acute ischemic stroke is 8 mg, followed by the remainder of the dose given as an infusion over 1 hour.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to OPD with rashes around his neck region, diarrhoea from the last 3 days, and recent forgetfulness. He is hailing from the northern states in India and is mainly surviving on a maize rich diet. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is most likely associated with his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin B3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms - dermatitis (especially in areas exposed to sunlight), diarrhea, and dementia (forgetfulness) - are characteristic of pellagra, which is caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is often associated with diets high in maize (corn), as maize is a poor source of niacin and lacks the amino acid tryptophan, which the body can use to synthesize niacin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency leads to beriberi, which presents with symptoms like weight loss, emotional disturbances, impaired sensory perception, weakness, and pain in the limbs, and periods of irregular heart rate. While neurological symptoms can occur, the overall clinical picture doesn't align with the patient's presentation.
  • • Option A
  • • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine):
  • • Option B . Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can cause ariboflavinosis, symptoms of which include sore throat, hyperemia, and edema of the pharyngeal and oral mucosa, cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and anemia. However, these symptoms are not as aligned with the patient's presentation as the symptoms of another vitamin deficiency.
  • • Option B
  • • Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin):
  • • Option D . Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to seborrheic dermatitis, microcytic anemia, electroencephalographic abnormalities, convulsions, and peripheral neuropathy. While some symptoms may overlap, the specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia is more indicative of niacin deficiency.
  • • Option D
  • • Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Casal’s Necklace shown in the figure occur due to Niacin deficiency (Pellagra) Pellagra is seen in people whose staple diet is maize. In maize, niacin is present but in a bound form and is unavailable to the body. Symptoms of pellagra: Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace. Diarrhea Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen.
  • ➤ Casal’s Necklace shown in the figure occur due to Niacin deficiency (Pellagra)
  • ➤ Pellagra is seen in people whose staple diet is maize.
  • ➤ In maize, niacin is present but in a bound form and is unavailable to the body.
  • ➤ Symptoms of pellagra: Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace. Diarrhea Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen.
  • ➤ Symptoms of pellagra:
  • ➤ Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace. Diarrhea Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen.
  • ➤ Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace.
  • ➤ Casal’s necklace.
  • ➤ Diarrhea
  • ➤ Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557749/
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557749/

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Article 21

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is critical as it enshrines the Right to Life and personal liberty, ensuring that every individual's life and personal freedoms are protected under the law.

questions.text: Which artery is used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis and is present behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendon calcaneus? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior tibial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibial artery is the artery located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein in procedures like hemodialysis access due to its superficial location and ease of access.
  • ➤ posterior tibial artery

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Bridging veins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognition of a subdural hemorrhage is crucial following head trauma, especially in individuals at higher risk such as the elderly, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with a history of alcohol abuse. Immediate medical evaluation is vital to manage the condition effectively and mitigate potential severe outcomes.
